11/8: Recent polls (most) continue to indicate a Trump lead. GA independents reportedly 'leaning'  Republican.. http://www.wsbtv.com/news/politics/poll-georgia-neck-and-neck-between-clinton-and-trump/464944425
Based on polling numbers and historical base rates, I show Trump between 52% and 69% probability of winning

11/7: Election-eve impression is that too much (overall) opposition to Hillary (etc.) still exists in generally red-state Georgia.  Recent polls may be closer, but Trump continues to lead in most. Hillary herself not campaigning here. One potential 'wildcard': Vote turnout could be high, possibly somewhat favorable for Hillary overall (ref. last source below) http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/georgia/ http://www.270towin.com/2016-polls-clinton-trump/georgia/ http://politics.blog.ajc.com/2016/11/03/nbcwsjmarist-poll-has-donald-trump-hillary-clinton-neck-and-neck-in-georgia/ http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-georgia-president-trump-vs-clinton http://www.dailyprogress.com/georgia-official-says-state-is-ready-for-tuesday-s-election/article_c3fb70b8-63f3-58cb-b82d-b3e595a2858d.html
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
I do not believe Secretary Clinton will carry North Carolina.  If North Carolina doesn't fall her way, then Georgia is definitely out of reach.

It's a Republican-leaning swing state, with the only Dems winnning here in the last 50 years Clinton (thanks to Ross Perot splitting the vote) and Carter twice. That gives us a baseline of 65% for Trump. The demographics look like they might benefit Clinton, with a high proportion of blacks (c.30%) and lower proportion of whites (less than 60%). Nevertheless, the polls are showing an easy Trump win.
It will be close, but this is moving towards Trump.

11/5: Not hearing of a Hillary visit to GA in last days....
Most, recent polls/analysis looked at continue to indicate at least a narrow lead for Trump there. http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/georgia/ http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/us/elections/polls.html? http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-georgia-president-trump-vs-clinton

Average of 6 Polls
Last Poll: Nov. 4
TRUMP 48%
Clinton 45%

I'm hesitant to make a 100% prediction, but with only a few days left in the election, I am confident Trump will win Georgia.  Trump has been up in every poll I've seen and despite Nate Silver giving him only a 83.7% chance, I don't see any chance of Hillary winning Georgia.
Apart from a blip, DT has consistently led by a secure enough margin.

Clinton is ahead in early voting 51% to Trump's 43%. Over 1.8M have voted early in that state.  538 has given Trump a solid 84% prob of winning: 
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/georgia/
Late polling data suggests some potential for a Clinton victory, but hard to overcome longstanding state dynamics.
The Clinton campaign has pulled back from Georgia.  Looks like too far a reach.

Trump is ahead in all recent polls, Nate Silver gives him a 86.6% chance of winning Georgia, how Georgia has voted in previous elections, and based on watching lots of news about the race and where they are campaigning.

I'm staying high, though, because Georgia's demographic shift is possibly being over-represented and Republicans traditionally under-perform in pre-election polls. The result will be close, but hopefully my forecast represents a bit of Brier value. http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/302275-why-clinton-and-trump-are-in-a-close-race-in-georgia
But. . .If early voting gives Clinton encouragement and her team dispatches a Big Gun to Georgia - Michelle or Bill, say - I'll change things down quite a bit.

I have found after talking to a lot of Trump supporters in the USA northwest and south that among many there is now an open acceptance and call for an authoritarian approach to government to "break through" the bureaucratic, costly and ineffective nature of our current democracy. I hear this view now openly espoused with regard to both international relations/ war, immigration to USA and local/ state law enforcement issues. It seems that much like the communism vs democracy nature of the cold war has given way to democratic socialism in many European, S American and other gov'ts globally, there is now a movement taking hold in both N America and Europe for democratic authoritarianism.

Georgia will stay R for this year.  By '20, and maybe by the midyears, enough damyankees and college graduates will be on the rolls, and enough Scared Olde White Guys will have died off, that the state might well rejoin the union then.  My party needs to figure out a way to appeal to voters who have learned to walk without bruising their knuckles, even in the South.  Probably we won't succeed in that until at least '20.   Not everybody in the South who supports Republicans is a Scared Olde White Guy, of course--there are a lot of responsible grownup conservatives in the Party everywhere, and even a sprinkling of moderates up in the Northeast.   However, the national party has painted us into an unattractive corner over the past few decades, and now our so-called core voters are a dying--literally--demographic.
If Trump can't make it there, he can't make it anywhere. . .
It's Georgia. There's a possibility for a dem win, but I think it will remain Republican.

Wow, this turned into quite the lengthy opinion piece that is about both the GA election and the Democrats approach to winning over moderate conservatives in general. Although I live elsewhere most of the year, I grew up in Georgia / still spend much of the year there, and I believe I have a deep well of anecdotal observations on what might play out in Nov in GA and the Democratic approach to the South in general. 
I know of two Georgias: Atlanta and the rest of GA (with Savannah and Athens in the middle politically). Atlanta not only is a huge proportion of GA's population, but it also has many people from other parts of the country with more progressive perspectives and lifestyles, a relatively large and politically active African American middle class, and many more African Americans living in poverty and under intense policing. Furthermore, Georgia as a whole has a 31% African American population and a 10% Hispanic population (2010 census). GA has several very large military bases with local communities extremely loyal to the US military. Given Trump's anti-NATO and pro-Putin stances, there is potential for Trump to suffer a low turnout among some of the military communities in GA. Furthermore, his coming out strongly on side of law enforcement on the ongoing cops/ black lives matter debate could see a large turnout for Clinton among both African Americans and progressive whites in Atlanta. And his blatant anti-Mexican jabs makes a golden opportunity for anyone running against Trump to get more of the 10% Hispanic population than any prior election in GA.
Although much of the municipal political leaders in GA cities, including Mayors and national congressmen elected by district, are well represented among African Americans, anyone who lives in GA knows that statewide election outcomes for some reason often do NOT reflect the same diversity. The state as a whole seems to almost always elect a very conservative governor who is almost always a "good old boy" well connected to and trusted by the major donors and economic power brokers in the state, many of whom are old money with historic ties and connections throughout the state. 
Then there’s the Clinton factor. I know a LOT of republicans in GA, and I only know of a few who cannot and will not support Trump and none of them will vote for Hillary. If the Democrats had elected ANYONE else, including Bernie Sanders, they would have had a better chance. Democrats simply do not understand the south and how to energize the progressive south. When Kerry picked John Edwards as his running mate as the Democrats’ attempt to win some southern votes, I immediately laughed and wondered how they could not know he has DESPISED among South Carolinians, especially women. Women in South Carolina could tell John Edwards was sleazebag even before the revelation of his amoral behavior in years after the election, and he was headed towards a state election loss when Kerry picked him. Did the Democrats not even do their homework??? I own a business in GA and a few years ago I had a group solar executives from Oregon approached me with a proposal for investing in a solar project in GA. When they arrived at my office, they had a person from GA acting as a local representative to introduce them and to “do the talking.” As it turned out I have spent much of my life in the USA NW and I was very open to talking with them all, but this should be lesson to Democrats nationwide: you must approach communicating with the south as a different culture because it simply is. Just like you need local representation in China to do business, you need it in the rural and small city south if you are foreign or from an entirely different American culture. Democrats have failed miserably to recognize this.
If you listen to southern progressives and actually know them as people (or better yet if you are actually a southern progressive surrounded by conservatives), you learn they are not coming to their progressive views in a such a conservative environment because they are drawn to the PC shaming of Democrats in the media. It borders on cliche, but GA has a "fighting spirit" and rebellious, deeply proud code of personal conduct and pride among people who grow up in the rural areas and smaller cities (I saw and lived it as a child and see it today in others who have never really lived outside the state). The GA progressive has this same fighting spirit that is usually seen among its vocal conservatives, and I think in fact southern progressives have it more than most because of how independent you must be to come to and vocalize progressive views in such a conservative environment. It is easy and expected to grow up in these conservative communities believing what your parents or your spouse thinks because it brings acceptance and positive reinforcement on a daily if not hourly level through your conversations at work, socially and at home. So to come from that mosaic of deeply conservative environments and become a progressive is an act of rebellion and resistance to what they see as the people they know well and love just having the wrong beliefs. Instead, the Democrats use PC shaming of the same conservatives who are the very co-community members, coworkers and even FAMILY members of those southern progressives. How is that helping those progressives express, much less convince others, of their views??? Are these lonely progressives supposed to turn on all these people and shame them into changing their views? This is why I belive PC shaming only reinforces existing democrats' views while keeping their viewpoints from actually gaining traction in otherwise mostly conservative communities. Even if they squeak a victory out of this election, the Democrats are not providing an avenue for the growth of progressive viewpoints in conservative places like the south and rural Northwest (places I know intimately well).  Independents and moderate conservatives nationwide that vote for Hillary will do so because of their denunciation of Trump, not because of any belief in Hillary Clinton. Furthermore, the PC shaming approach of Democrats will mean many of these potential swing voters will simply stay home- not enough for Hillary to win GA.
This is an unusual reference for this forum, but if you listen to the music of many southern progressives (Allman Brothers, Drive-by Truckers, Widespread Panic etc), you will hear the same anti-establishment spit and fire that you here from conservatives like Newt Gingrich, but in expression of progressive views. Democrats need to learn this and to motivate southern progressives by recognizing they are rebelling against their own conservative surroundings as much as GA conservatives have and seemingly always will tend to rebel against the Democratic party in every forum possible. This is the spirit in the rural and small city southern culture that forms the backbone of resistance to the PC shaming, but this same spirit can be harnessed as a powerful, fresh voice that Democrats would find to be amazingly effective in the South compared to PC shaming from afar. Somehow intertwine that with the Bernie-inspired movement across the rest of the nation, and the Democrats would have something powerful.

Georgia has been trending more democratic in recent elections, but polls have still consistently shown Trump with a lead of around 4-5%.  In a blowout win for Hillary she could win Georgia, but in a closer election I don't think the demographics have shifted enough to flip Georgia Democratic.

Georgia  hasn't voted for a Democrat presidential candidate since Bill Clinton in 1992.  The Real Clear Politics average currently shows Trump leading Hillary by 46.0% to 41.5%.
http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/ga/georgia_trump_vs_clinton-5741.html Speculation that Georgia may become competitive has yet to be borne out, even if demographics are shifting somewhat away from the Republicans.  Although the Washington Post article cited by GJO does say the state may be competitive this year, they still have it as "lean Republican" and end with  "There was much excitement among Democrats in 2014 about Michelle Nunn's Senate candidacy in the Peach State. She wound up losing by eight points to a wealthy businessman making his first run for elected office. Sound familiar?
Georgia is considered a weakly favored state for Trump by some analysts, notably Electionprojection.com.  But Georgia has not voted for a Democrat in a presidential race since 1992.

Georgia is traditionally a conservative State; however, the people there are intelligent enough to realize that, Trump is not a traditional conservative. If it had been Jeb Bush, Georgia would be an easy win for the Republicans. For all their Southern charm, Georgians don't trust quickly. Trump is just too far out for their comfort. The only way that will change is if Trump spends some time on camera with their governor, sipping iced tea on his back porch in a rocking chair and goes to the State Fair. If he caught a greased pig at the fair, and ate some home made pie, then they would love him enough to accept him as one of their own. Right now he's like an alien to them.

Mostly rural, Deep South state. It is Atlanta Region vs. rest of Georgia. it also part of bible belt. The not will depend on Georgia conservatives attitude toward Trump, considered by many conservatives not a true conservative.

Safe win for Donald. 538 also gives this as landslide win to the Big D.
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/georgia/
Going with 538's guess of 20% Hillary, 80% Donald.  Nether party will spend much time here, so staying with 538.
Georgia has gone Republican since 1996, and Clinton is not the sort of candidate to change people's loyalties.

Here are some US Census figures for the state of Georgia: Population estimates, July 1, 2015: 10,214,860 
Race and Origin:
White alone, July 1, 2015: 61.6%
Black or African American alone, percent, July 1, 2015: 31.7%
American Indian and Alaska Native alone, percent, July 1, 2015: 0.5%
Asian alone, percent, July 1, 2015: 4.0%
Hispanic or Latino, July 1, 2015: 9.4% Veterans, 2010-2014: 681,840
High school graduate or higher, age 25 years+, 2010-2014: 85.0%
Bachelor's degree or higher: 2010-2014: 28.3%
In civilian labor force: 2010-2014:  62.6%
Median household income (in 2014 dollars): $49,342
Per capita income in past 12 months (in 2014 dollars): $25,427
Persons in poverty: 18.3% Minority-owned firms, 2012 - 371,588
Veteran-owned firms, 2012 96,787 Poverty rate is higher than New York, just for comparison sake.  The number of people without health insurance is higher, too (Georgia 17.9% vs 15.4% in the US) 
and so is unemployment (5.1%, the US latest June 2016 figure is 4.9)  The state is the 6th in the country for undocumented immigrants. 490,000 est.
There were 743,000 veterans in 2009. There are some massive voter registration drives going on in Georgia, mostly of minority groups.  As with other highly contested states, we have to take a look at the campaign operation that will be mounted in the state by each candidate and their ability to drive the vote.  Looking at rough stats, this looks like a state that will vote for Trump but we cannot dismiss the primary results when considering factors.  Presumably, Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz supporters will go with Trump.  In a state like this, the matter of immigration will weight heavily and so is the matter of all that is at stake at the SCOTUS nominations.  I'm increasing my forecast in favor of a Trump win for now but will keep a close eye on each candidate's campaign efforts there.
Demographics have shifted some; registrations and turnout will be key here, and it's too early to guess accurately about that (at least for me).
Trump might have dropped out by election night.
Outside of some cataclysmic event, it's hard to see where Clinton finds the votes to win here.

538 currently has Trump leading by ~6%. I suspect that'll be down to 3-5% by Labor Day. I'm giving Clinton a somewhat higher chance of winning in Georgia than 538 in part because of that and in part because there's a small but definite chance of a larger national win, in which case GA is much more in play. Not very likely -- something like a 10% chance. But possible.

In the Democratic Primaries, Hillary won with an overwhelming 71.3% 543,008 compared to Sanders 28%. Trump won the Republican primary with not such impressive numbers, he received 38.8%
(501,707), Marco Rubio got 24.4% (315,979), Ted Cruz 23.6% (305,109), Carson 6.2% (80,503) Georgia has voted REPUBLICAN in the last 5 presidential elections. It hasn't voted for a democrat since it voted for CLINTON in 1992. http://www.270towin.com/states/Georgia  That's significant.  Polls between Hillary and Trump give Trump the lead by anything between 2-4%.  Some put both candidates surprisingly close which tells me we need to take a closer look at what is going on in the state in terms of voting demographics and other factors such as, my pet peeves, campaign infrastructure, investment and operations and economic data.   NOTE:  Just the fact that a Red State such as this one would be the subject of a forecasting question tells us something may be up in the state and we should use our "good judgement" training lol Not taking anything for granted on this election.  Giving Trump a small edge given the state's voting history and the polls but will need to research more.
This is still a red state when the final vote totals are in.  A different Democrat might be able to take the state but Hillary is not the person to do so in Georgia.

Based on the NY Times Upshot average for models reporting a percentage. Unweighted.
http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/upshot/presidential-polls-forecast.html

Georgia has gone Republican for 7 out of the last 10 elections, and has gone Republican in every presidential election since 1996. This trend favors Trump: http://www.270towin.com/states/Georgia Polls show a fairly close race, but Trump has been consistently polling ahead of Clinton since October: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/ga/georgia_trump_vs_clinton-5741.html We should also note that Trump won Georgia by a wide margin in the primaries.  It is true that Georgia is 30% black (which should help Clinton), but the long-term tendency in presidential elections is that Georgia swings Republican, and polling data indicates that 2016 will be no different.
Polls show DT with 1 to 9 point leads over the past year.  Starting at 50/50, strong increase in HRC polls after convention may change the outlook.
